Russell & Norvig describe entropy as a measure of the uncertainty of a random variable, and mention that the acquisition of information corresponds to a reduction in entropy. In order to determine the information gain of any dierent attributes of a certain collection of data, the calculation of entropy is important the notion of information gain is de ned in terms of entropy. Entropy can be described as a measure of impurity of an arbitrary collection of examples. Russell & Norvig describe entropy as a measure of the uncertainty of a random variable, and mention that the acquisition of information corresponds to a reduction in entropy. Namely a random variable with only one value has no uncertainty and thus its entropy is de ned as zero; thus we gain no information by observing its value. For any attribute A, if no information can be gained regarding the decision from attribute A, then the entropy of attribute A is equal to 0. In order to determine the information gain of any dierent attributes of a certain collection of data, the calculation of entropy is important the notion of information gain is de ned in terms of entropy. Entropy can be described as a measure of impurity of an arbitrary collection of examples. Russell & Norvig describe entropy as a measure of the uncertainty of a random variable, and mention that the acquisition of information corresponds to a reduction in entropy. Namely a random variable with only one value has no uncertainty and thus its entropy is de ned as zero; thus we gain no information by observing its value. For any attribute A, if no information can be gained regarding the decision from attribute A, then the entropy of attribute A is equal to 0. If all the members of a class are split equally by any attribute A, then the entropy of A is 1. For any collection S the maximum entropy value is 1. Entropy can be described as a measure of impurity of an arbitrary collection of examples. Russell & Norvig describe entropy as a measure of the uncertainty of a random variable, and mention that the acquisition of information corresponds to a reduction in entropy. Namely a random variable with only one value has no uncertainty and thus its entropy is deï¬ned as zero; thus we gain no information by observing its value. For any attribute A, if no information can be gained regarding the decision from attribute A, then the entropy of attribute A is equal to 0. If all the members of a class are split equally by any attribute A, then the entropy of A is 1. For any collection S the maximum entropy value is 1.
